sentence.text: Naive CD4+ T cells adhere to tumor slices in proportion to the abundance of monocyte chemotaxis-producing macrophages.
Moreover, adoptively transferred human naive CD4+ T cells infiltrate human breast cancer orthotopic xenografts in a monocyte chemotaxis-dependent manner.

In human breast cancer xenografts in humanized mice, blocking the recruitment of naive CD4+ T cells into tumor by knocking down the expression of ER to Golgi vesicle-mediated transport, a monocyte chemotaxis receptor, significantly reduces intratumoral Tregs and inhibits tumor progression.

Inhibiting naive CD4+ T cell recruitment into tumors by interfering with ER to Golgi vesicle-mediated transport recognition of monocyte chemotaxis may be an attractive strategy for anticancer immunotherapy

In human breast cancer xenografts in humanized mice, blocking the recruitment of naive CD4+ T cells into tumor by knocking down the expression of ER to Golgi vesicle-mediated transport, a CCL18 receptor, significantly reduces intratumoral Tregs and inhibits tumor progression.
